reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s baseline conditional distribution in Sec. 3.1 (“no serious coordinated de dicto optimization”) and argues that the default is instead strong optimization by concentrated institutional interests, making ‘common-sense utopia’ unrealistic and shifting the dominant failure mode from philosophical moral error to institutional lock-in/low-flourishing equilibria. This is moderately central: the essay’s main conclusion is about the narrowness/fragility of mostly-great futures even given survival and without deliberate de dicto optimization; changing the baseline could affect the estimated prevalence and types of non-eutopian futures. However, even if the critique is right, it doesn’t directly undermine the core claim that eutopia is a narrow target due to many independent moral/value-sensitive dimensions; it mainly suggests an additional (perhaps dominant) pathway to missing eutopia. Strength is therefore limited: it weakens the framing and the “catalog” emphasis, but doesn’t refute the multiplicative fragility argument or the Section 3 ‘fussiness of value functions’ claim. Correctness is fairly high as a plausible sociopolitical point (defaults often involve power optimization and capture), but it is asserted without evidence and overstates (“the default is not no one optimizes”) given the essay’s explicit conditioning on absence of de dicto optimization rather than absence of all optimization. The critique is clear and mostly focused on one issue, with little dead weight. Overall quality is moderate insight but low refutational impact on the position, so the overall score is anchored near centrality×strength and adjusted slightly upward for relevance/clarity.
title: Institutional capture by powerful actors is the real baseline risk
